article.title: Mice in Bion-M 1 Space Mission: Training and Selection
funding: Division of Physiology and Fundamental Medicine of Russian Academy of Sciences
article.abstract: After a 16-year hiatus, Russia has resumed its program of biomedical research in space, with the successful 30-day flight of the Bion-M 1 biosatellite (April 19–May 19, 2013). The principal species for biomedical research in this project was the mouse. This paper presents an overview of the scientific goals, the experimental design and the mouse training/selection program.

sections.introduction: After a 16-year hiatus, Russia resumed in 2013 its program of biomedical research in space, with the successful 30-day flight of the Bion-M 1 biosatellite (April 19–May 19, 2013), a specially designed automated spacecraft dedicated to life-science experiments.
sections.methods: Experiments were performed with C57BL/6N male mice.
sections.results: In the flight (SF) experiment 16 out of 45 mice (36%) survived and in the ground control (GC) experiment, 38 out of 45 mice (84%) survived.
sections.discussion: The overall success was evident: aggressive interactions were noted on single occasions and under conditions of starvation only.

experimental_factors.treatment_raw: microgravity,ionizing radiation,hindlimb unloading,exercise training,cyclic passive stretch

article.insights_summary: The study presents an overview of the scientific goals, the experimental design and the mouse training/selection program for the Bion-M 1 space mission. The results demonstrate that group housed male mice can be successfully employed in space biomedical research if clear and simple procedures are followed.
